description.narrative:
Denna insats syftar till att genomföra en organisationsöversyn av UHAI. Översynen innebär en kartläggning och bedömning av UHAI’s interna kapacitet som organisation.
Den östafrikanska organisationen UHAI- EASHRI har fått projektstöd från Sida’s enhet för demokrati och mänskliga rättigheter sedan 2009. Ansvaret för Sidas stöd till UHAI flyttades från Sida HQ till Svenska ambassaden i Lusaka den 1 januari 2017.
UHAI är en organisation ledd av aktivister som arbetar för att kvinnor i prostitution och sexuella minoritetsgrupper i östra Afrika ska få tillgång till sina mänskliga rättigheter. Sedan starten 2009 har UHAI stött det civila samhället i länderna i Burundi, Kenya, Rwanda, Tanzania och Uganda, och planerar för närvarande att utöka sitt arbete till att omfatta Etiopien och Demokratiska republiken Kongo.

This contribution is set up for the procurement of an organisational assessment to be carried out for the East African organisation UHAI. The East African Sexual Health And Rights Initative, UHAI- EASHRI, has received project support from the Sida Unit for Democracy and Human Rights (hereinafter DEMO – unit) since 2009. The management of Sida’s support to UHAI was transitioned from Sida HQ to the Embassy of Sweden in Lusaka on the 1st January 2017. Part of the ambition of this transition is to review the partnership and assess the possibility for Sida to render support under the Swedish Government’s Strategy for Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights for Sub-Saharan Africa 2015 - 2019, and to explore the possibility to shift from project to core support. Based in Nairobi, UHAI is an East African activist led foundation that works for the rights of sex workers and sexual and gender minorities in Eastern Africa. Since their founding in 2009, UHAI has provided sub-grants to civil society organisations that work within the confines of sex work and LGBTI. They support organisations based in Burundi, Kenya, Rwanda, Tanzania, and Uganda, and are currently planning to expand their work to include Ethiopia and Democratic Republic of Congo. Four of UHAI's sub-grantee partners have been selected to be assessed under the 2017 organisational assessment. The overaching goal of Sida’s support to UHAI through these support periods have been to enable LGBTI and sex worker organisations access flexible funds, partnerships and capacity building opportunities in order to strengthen the LGBTI and sex worker movements in the region.
